summary: Nipah virus (NiV), a virus of the genus Henipavirus within the Paramyxoviridae family, is an emerging zoonotic pathogen that was first isolated in 1999. some serological surveys revealed that NiV has a wide host range, including humans, pigs, dogs, cats, horses, goats, hamsters, and fruit bats. type I IFNs induce phosphorylation of tyrosine kinase 2 and Janus kinase 1. these kinases activate signal transducer and activator of transcription 1 (STAT1) and STAT2 via phosphorylation at the tyrosine residues (18–20) STAT2 is constitutively associated with IFN regulatory factor 9 (IRF9) and the STAT1/STAT2/IRF9 transcription factor complex is called IFN-sti the MV-N protein of measles virus (MV-N) inhibits host IFN responses by disrupting the JAK/STAT signaling pathway. the protein possesses a nuclear localization signal (NLS) that is a leucine/isoleucine-rich motif within the N-terminal region. we compared the IFN antagonism of the N protein (NiV-N, HeV-N, and MV-N) to that of the P gene products. all the N, P, V, and W proteins significantly suppressed type I and type II IFN responses. the coexpression of N and P proteins did not reduce their IFN antagonist activity. 293T cells were transfected with reporter plasmids, phRL-TK (Int) and pCAGGS-MV-N, -HeV-N, -NiV-N, or -NiV-P or pCMV-myc-NiV-P. at 24 h posttransfection, reporter assays were conducted. expression levels of NiV-Nc, NiV-Nt, HeV-Nc, and -Nt in 293T cells. the experiment was conducted three times, and a representative blot is shown. it has been reported that paramyxovirus N proteins consist of two major domains. the tail domain of the NiV-N protein diffused throughout the cell. the protein can therefore potentially affect any step of the IFN signal transduction pathway (40). cos7 or HeLa cells were transfected with 0.6 g of the pCAGGS-NiV-N or -NiV-N-HA expression plasmid. the cells were stained with anti-STAT1, -pSTAT1, -STAT2 and -pSTAT2 antibodies. the images shown are all z-stack data. DISCUSSION In paramyxoviruses, the P gene products block host IFN responses. nuclear transport of STATs through degradation of nup153 and p62 proteins. this suppression results in the indiscriminant prevention of host protein translocation to the nucleus. henipavirus N proteins does not affect the nuclear pore complex to prevent STAT transfer. the inhibition of IFN- responses by the N protein was weaker than that induced by the P protein. however, the inhibition of IFN- responses by the N protein was weaker than that induced by the P protein. this suggests that the IFN antagonism of N protein is comparable to that of the P gene products. coexpression of the mutant P protein (mP) did not abrogate the IFN suppression by the N protein. this indicates that N-P interaction does not impair the antagonistic activity. this is consistent with the finding that IFN inhibition by the N protein was due to the suppression of STAT complex formation.
